study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of essential fatty acids (EFA) in preventing Alzheimer's disease (AD) by addressing lipid metabolism disturbances caused by high carbohydrate diets.
results_summary: The study suggests that increasing EFA intake, alongside reducing dietary carbohydrates, may help prevent AD by restoring lipid homeostasis and mitigating insulin/IGF signaling damage in cerebral neurons. However, no direct clinical results or efficacy data on EFA supplementation are provided.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease, particularly those with the apoE4 allele.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of essential fatty acids (EFA), particularly n-3 fatty acids, against common cancers and their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 fatty acids, including DHA and EPA, exhibit protective effects against cancers like breast, colon, and prostate by inhibiting neoplastic transformation, promoting apoptosis, and modulating inflammatory pathways. They also enhance the efficacy of chemopreventive agents in breast cancer patients and improve the balance between cell proliferation and apoptosis in colorectal cancer.
population_specificity: Patients with breast and colorectal cancer, as well as general populations with traditional diets like that of Crete.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of oral supplementation of essential fatty acids (EFA) as phospholipids (PL) versus triglycerides (TG) in preventing EFA deficiency in cholestatic and noncholestatic mice.
results_summary: EFA-rich PL was more effective than EFA-rich TG in reducing liver and brain EFA deficiency markers and increasing long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCPUFA) concentrations in cholestatic mice, while both forms were equally effective in noncholestatic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with induced EFA deficiency, including a subgroup with extrahepatic cholestasis.
study_duration: 3 weeks of supplementation after 3 weeks of EFA-deficient diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the adequacy of fat and essential fatty acid (EFA) intake in children with phenylketonuria (PKU) and evaluate the effects of an EFA-supplemented protein substitute.
results_summary: The test-treatment group (EFA-supplemented) showed higher fat and EFA intakes compared to the control group, bringing intakes closer to population norms. Young children in the control group were particularly vulnerable to poor fat and alpha-linolenic acid (alpha-LA) intakes.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-10 years with phenylketonuria (PKU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of lithium salt of gamma-linolenic acid conjugated to iodized lymphographic oil (LGIOC) on tumor-feeding vessel occlusion and tumor size reduction in stage 4 cancer patients.
results_summary: LGIOC injection led to complete and near-permanent occlusion of tumor-feeding vessels and significant tumor size reduction in all four patients, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Four stage 4 cancer patients (2 hepatocellular carcinoma, 1 giant cell tumor of the bone, 1 renal cell carcinoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of TNF-alpha and essential fatty acid deficiency (EFAD) on lipid profile, lipoprotein composition, and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in rats.
results_summary: EFAD significantly increased plasma triglycerides, total cholesterol, and HDL-cholesterol. TNF-alpha further elevated triglycerides in controls but not EFAD rats, modified lipoprotein-lipid composition, and decreased LPL activity, with more pronounced effects in EFAD rats.
population_specificity: EFAD-induced rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 EFA on antioxidant enzyme and oxidant parameters in the corpus striatum of rats, potentially supporting its therapeutic role in neuropsychiatric disorders like schizophrenia.
results_summary: Omega-3 EFA significantly reduced oxidant parameters (TBARS, NO, XO) and increased antioxidant enzyme activity (t-SOD) in the corpus striatum of rats, suggesting a protective effect against oxidative stress-related neuronal injury.
population_specificity: Rats (8 control, 9 treated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of essential fatty acid (EPA) and non-essential fatty acid (ETA) on tumor cell parameters linked to progression and metastasis.
results_summary: EPA showed anti-proliferative effects across all tested tumor cell lines, while ETA had mixed effects, sometimes promoting and other times inhibiting tumor-related parameters. The study concluded that EPA exhibited beneficial effects, whereas ETA showed inconsistent and sometimes adverse effects.
population_specificity: Human tumor cell lines (T-24 from urothelium, MCF-7 from breast, and HRT-18 from colon).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) isomers modulate essential fatty acid (EFA) metabolism and their effects on tumor cell growth and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) synthesis.
results_summary: The study found that CLA isomers, particularly D10t,12c-18:2, significantly inhibited arachidonic acid (AA) synthesis from linoleic acid (LA), reduced tumor cell growth, and decreased PGE2 synthesis. All CLA treatments reduced tumor cell growth by more than half compared to LA controls.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 mammary tumor cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic role of lactic acid bacteria (LAB) in improving essential fatty acid (EFA) status in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
results_summary: The study suggests that LAB may improve EFA status in CFS patients, who often exhibit altered EFA levels, by protecting the intestinal epithelial barrier and enhancing nutrient absorption. However, specific quantitative outcomes or statistical significance regarding EFA improvement were not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) on individuals with schizophrenia, focusing on their potential antipsychotic properties and impact on mental state.
results_summary: The study found modest evidence suggesting omega-3 EFAs may have antipsychotic properties and improve mental state in schizophrenia, though results were inconsistent and based on small, short-term trials. No clear differences were observed between different types of omega-3 EFAs, and omega-6 EFAs showed no clear effects on tardive dyskinesia.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia, including both medicated and unmedicated patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the sources, metabolism, and biological effects of alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), particularly its role as a precursor to EPA and DHA and its potential impacts on cardiovascular and neural health.
results_summary: The study found that ALA is primarily metabolized via beta-oxidation, accumulates in specific body tissues, and has limited conversion to DHA. Emerging evidence suggests ALA-rich diets may reduce total deaths and sudden cardiac death, though its direct effects on cardiovascular and neural function remain debated.
population_specificity: Various populations, including in vitro, animal, and human intervention studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish biochemical cut-off values for diagnosing essential fatty acid deficiency (EFAD), omega3-deficiency, and omega3/DHA-deficiency using erythrocyte fatty acid ratios.
results_summary: The study identified age-dependent cut-off values for EFAD and omega3-related deficiencies, applying them to various populations, including malnourished children and patients with fat-malabsorption disorders. The cut-off values effectively classified deficiency states, suggesting utility for targeted PUFA supplementation.
population_specificity: Breast-fed newborns, low-birth-weight infants, children, adults, vegans, malnourished Pakistani children, and pediatric patients with fat-malabsorption disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic renal failure (CRF) patients on maintenance haemodialysis treatment (MHT) exhibit essential fatty acid (EFA) deficiency and to characterize the specific fatty acid profile abnormalities.
results_summary: The study confirmed EFA deficiency in CRF patients on MHT, showing significantly decreased levels of n-6 fatty acids and PUFAs, while MUFAs were increased, suggesting a profile consistent with chronic inflammation. The findings align with immune activation due to dialysis membrane bio-incompatibility.
population_specificity: 14 chronic renal failure (CRF) patients on maintenance haemodialysis treatment (MHT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of essential fatty acids (EFA) in prostaglandin synthesis, their impact on metabolic processes, and their potential in cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that EFAs, particularly EPA and DHA, are crucial for prostaglandin synthesis and may help prevent cancer by inhibiting COX-2, which is linked to tumorigenesis. NSAIDs that suppress COX-2 activity were also noted to reduce cancer incidence.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human metabolism and cancer mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of dietary cholesterol on fatty acid desaturases in animals fed a low-EFA diet and its implications for polyunsaturated fatty acid synthesis.
results_summary: The study found that adding cholesterol to a low-EFA diet increased liver stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 activity and oleic/palmitoleic acid levels but decreased delta6 and delta5 desaturase activity, reducing arachidonic acid and DHA synthesis. This suggests dietary cholesterol may exacerbate EFA deficiency by impairing polyunsaturated fatty acid production.
population_specificity: Animals (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Essential fatty acids (EFA) in treating canine atopic dermatitis (AD) and assess the methodological quality of existing studies on this topic.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that while EFAs have potential mechanisms to modulate allergic inflammation, existing studies suffer from significant methodological flaws, leading to insufficient evidence to recommend their use for canine AD. Future trials need better design, longer duration, and standardized protocols.
population_specificity: Canine (dogs with atopic dermatitis)
study_duration: Not specified (but notes that future trials should last at least 3 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if PKU patients in the U.S. had adequate essential fatty acid (EFA) intake and whether they could synthesize long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids.
results_summary: The study found no clinically significant EFA deficiency in PKU patients, with comparable fatty acid levels in plasma and erythrocytes between patients and siblings. Patients appeared capable of synthesizing long-chain fatty acids from C18 precursors.
population_specificity: Children (1-13 years) with classic PKU and their non-PKU siblings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake assessed via 3-day diet diaries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the protective effects of a balanced ratio of (n-6):(n-3) essential fatty acids (EFA) within the traditional Greek diet, particularly in relation to lower cancer risk.
results_summary: The study found that the traditional Greek diet, which includes a balanced ratio of (n-6):(n-3) EFAs, is associated with lower rates of cancer, including breast cancer, due to its combination of protective nutrients like antioxidants, vitamins, and fiber. The dietary pattern of Crete, rich in EFAs, was highlighted for its potential cancer-preventive properties.
population_specificity: Mediterranean populations, specifically Greeks (pre-1960 diet) and Cretans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different therapies, including Essential fatty acid (EFA), in treating symmetrical lupoid onychodystrophy (SLO) in dogs.
results_summary: EFA therapy resulted in one good response, one partial response, and one failure out of three cases, indicating mixed efficacy in treating SLO. The study found no treatment was universally effective.
population_specificity: Six dogs diagnosed with symmetrical lupoid onychodystrophy (SLO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the intestinal absorption and lymphatic transport of tocopherol and retinol when delivered with structured triglycerides (STG) versus a physical mixture (PM) under normal conditions and after ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury.
results_summary: The study found that STG significantly enhanced the lymphatic transport of tocopherol and retinol compared to PM, achieving earlier steady-state outputs and maintaining approximately 30% higher outputs over 8 hours in both control and I/R groups.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (food-deprived, with or without I/R injury).
effective_dosage: 1 mL of fish oil/MCT STG or PM, along with (14)C-alpha-tocopherol and (3)H-retinol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential efficacy of Essential fatty acid (EFA) dietary supplementation in treating obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), drawing parallels to its use in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
results_summary: The study reported a 40% reduction in OCD symptoms (measured by YBOC scale) in a single subject after 13 weeks of ibuprofen use, suggesting that EFA supplementation might similarly improve neuronal membrane integrity and symptom severity. However, the evidence is limited to a case report without direct EFA intervention.
population_specificity: A single subject with OCD and comorbid paresthesia.
effective_dosage: Not specified for EFA (ibuprofen dosage not detailed).
interactions: None mentioned for EFA (ibuprofen's interaction with prostaglandin synthase and phospholipases noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an EFA-rich energy supplement could improve weight, body fat, and EFA status in underweight cystic fibrosis patients with steatorrhea.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in energy intake, weight for height, body fat, and plasma phospholipid linoleic and arachidonic acid levels compared to the control group, indicating improved EFA status and metabolic synthesis.
population_specificity: Underweight cystic fibrosis patients (aged >4 years) with steatorrhea and EFA depletion.
effective_dosage: 628 ± 254 mL/day (providing 31% energy from fat, 16% from linoleic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined high-dose growth hormone and glutamine (GH + GLN) improved intestinal absorption of fatty acids, including essential fatty acids (EFA), and EFA status in short bowel patients.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in intestinal absorption of fatty acids or EFA status with GH + GLN treatment. Only one patient showed signs of EFA deficiency, and no significant changes in body composition were observed compared to placebo, though lean body mass increased compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Short bowel patients (n=8)
effective_dosage: Growth hormone (mean 0.12 mg/kg/day) plus oral glutamine (mean 28 g/day) and parenteral glutamine (mean 5.2 g/day)

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of supplementing standard antipsychotic treatment with polyunsaturated fatty acids (EFAs or non-essential) in schizophrenia and assess EFA's efficacy as a sole antipsychotic treatment.
results_summary: Early results suggest a positive effect of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) over placebo for mental state outcomes, with one small study indicating EPA may help avoid standard antipsychotics in some cases. No clear effects were observed for primrose oil (omega-6) supplementation.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia.
study_duration: Up to 12 weeks in one study

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical research on abnormalities in membrane fatty acid composition and metabolism in schizophrenia and evaluate therapeutic trials of fatty acids for this disorder.
results_summary: The study found red blood cell fatty acid membrane abnormalities, increased phospholipid turnover via NMR spectroscopy, and a therapeutic effect of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation alongside neuroleptic treatment in some schizophrenia patients. However, findings were inconsistent, and greater attention to factors like diet and substance use is needed.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between the L-arginine-nitric oxide system and essential fatty acid metabolism in diabetes, particularly focusing on the effects of nitric oxide on delta-6- and delta-5-desaturase activities.
results_summary: The study found that L-arginine and sodium nitroprusside treatment in diabetic rats restored levels of essential fatty acids (LA, GLA, DGLA) and improved desaturase activities, while nitric oxide synthase inhibition reversed these benefits. Insulin treatment also normalized essential fatty acid metabolism abnormalities.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between essential fatty acid (EFA) deficiency and ADHD symptoms, and whether EFA supplementation could improve behavioral and health outcomes in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that children with ADHD and lower proportions of n-3 fatty acids exhibited more behavioral problems, temper tantrums, and learning, health, and sleep issues. A subgroup of ADHD subjects with symptoms of EFA deficiency had significantly lower plasma levels of arachidonic acid and docosahexaenoic acid compared to controls.
population_specificity: Children with clinically diagnosed ADHD exhibiting symptoms of EFA deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to replicate a previous study to determine if Efamol Marine (an EFA supplement) improved symptoms in patients with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) under current research criteria.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in symptoms with Efamol Marine compared to placebo, and no significant differences in red-cell membrane lipids between CFS patients and healthy controls. These results contrasted with a prior study reporting 85% symptom improvement.
population_specificity: Fifty patients meeting the Oxford Criteria for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation with omega-6 EFAs (GLA-rich EPO or LA) could restore plasma EFA levels and improve skin symptoms in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: EPO supplementation significantly increased plasma dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid and improved skin symptoms (dryness, pruritus, erythema) compared to baseline, while LA supplementation increased plasma LA but reduced docosahexaenoic acid. EPO showed a trend toward greater improvement in pruritus than LA.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with uremic skin symptoms (9 in EPO group, 7 in LA group).
effective_dosage: 2 g/day of either GLA-rich EPO or LA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between essential fatty acid (EFA) levels and immunopathological/clinical disease status in primary Sjögren's syndrome patients.
results_summary: Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) levels inversely correlated with clinical disease status, while dihomogammalinolenic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) levels inversely correlated with IgM rheumatoid factors and anti-SSA/Ro antibodies, respectively. The n-3/n-6 EFA ratios also significantly correlated with disease status, supporting EFA's anti-inflammatory role.
population_specificity: 41 primary Sjögren's syndrome patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of essential fatty acids (EFA) in urinary tract tumorigenesis, focusing on the effects of EFA deficiency and high intake of non-EFAs.
results_summary: The study found that chronic EFA deficiency in rodents led to urolithiasis, transitional hyperplasias, and increased risk of urinary tract tumorigenesis. High intake of saturated fats or non-EFAs, which may induce EFA deficiency, was associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer in case-control studies, while EFAs showed potential benefits in cancer prevention and therapy in other cell populations.
population_specificity: Rodents and human case-control studies (bladder cancer risk).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the mechanisms of fatty acid uptake by placental cells, focusing on the role of the placental plasma membrane fatty acid-binding protein (p-FABPpm) in the preferential uptake of essential fatty acids (EFA) and long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCPUFA).
results_summary: The study found that BeWo cells preferentially uptake docosahexaenoic acid, arachidonic acid, and linoleic acid over oleic acid, mediated by p-FABPpm. Docosahexaenoic acid was mainly incorporated into triacylglycerol, suggesting its role in placental transport to fetal circulation.
population_specificity: Cultured human placental choriocarcinoma (BeWo) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether altered essential fatty acid (EFA) metabolism contributes to sepsis pathogenesis and whether restoring EFA metabolism could be a therapeutic approach for sepsis and critical illnesses.
results_summary: The study proposed that EFA deficiency and altered metabolism may underlie sepsis pathogenesis, leading to imbalanced inflammatory responses. It suggested that normalizing EFA metabolism could be a novel therapeutic strategy for sepsis prevention and management.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical proposal, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of MCT supplementation, including its percentage, on fat absorption, growth, nutritional status, and clinical outcomes in children with cholestatic liver disease, with specific attention to EFA deficiency.
results_summary: Higher percentage MCT was associated with EFA deficiency (4/4 studies), but no direct efficacy of EFA supplementation was evaluated. The study primarily noted adverse effects (EFA deficiency) rather than benefits.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years with cholestatic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether essential fatty acids (EFAs) and their metabolites could reverse growth arrest in Ca2+ pool-depleted smooth muscle cells and identify the specific signaling pathways involved.
results_summary: The study found that EFAs, particularly arachidonic acid and its cytochrome P-450 epoxygenase metabolites (8,9- and 11,12-EET), effectively restored Ca2+ pools and cell growth in thapsigargin-treated cells, while inhibitors of other metabolic pathways had no effect. Serum-induced recovery was also mediated by EFAs, highlighting their role in reversing growth arrest.
population_specificity: DDT1MF-2 smooth muscle cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of essential fatty acids (EFA) in treating infantile seborrheic dermatitis (ISD) and assess the relationship between Malassezia furfur and clinical symptoms.
results_summary: The study found aberrant EFA patterns in children with ISD, characterized by elevated levels of 18:1w9 and 20:2w6. Topical treatment with borage oil (25% GLA) led to complete healing, but M. furfur growth was unaffected, suggesting no direct link between the fungus and clinical symptoms.
population_specificity: 21 children diagnosed with infantile seborrheic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Topical borage oil containing 25% gammalinolenic acid (GLA) (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Treatment until complete healing, with follow-up after 1 year.

study_goal: To determine if oral omega-3 EFA supplementation induces neuroprotective changes in the corneal sub-basal nerve plexus and correlates with clinical improvements in dry eye disease.
results_summary: Omega-3 EFA supplementation led to greater reductions in OSDI scores and tear osmolarity compared to placebo, suggesting neuroprotective effects in the corneal sub-basal plexus correlated with tear osmolarity normalization.
population_specificity: 12 participants with moderate dry eye disease (final subset of a 60-participant trial).
effective_dosage: ~1000 mg/day eicosapentaenoic acid + ~500 mg/day docosahexaenoic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of two forms of omega-3 EFAs (krill oil and fish oil) versus placebo in treating dry eye disease (DED).
results_summary: Both krill oil and fish oil significantly reduced tear osmolarity and improved tear stability compared to placebo. Krill oil additionally reduced DED symptoms and inflammatory cytokine levels, suggesting potential added benefits over fish oil.
population_specificity: 60 participants with mild to moderate dry eye disease.
effective_dosage: Krill oil (945 mg/day EPA + 510 mg/day DHA), fish oil (1000 mg/day EPA + 500 mg/day DHA), placebo (1500 mg/day olive oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a nitrogen additive containing essential oils from garlic and cinnamon on gastrointestinal worm resistance and performance in lambs.
results_summary: The nitrogen additive with essential oils reduced parasitic load in lambs compared to the control group but did not improve productive performance or diet intake efficiency. Essential oils showed an anthelmintic effect, suggesting potential for managing gastrointestinal nematodes in small ruminants.
population_specificity: Fourteen male sheep, average age 18 months, initial body weight 23.5 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of essential oils against bacterial strains isolated from chronic wounds and assess their potential as alternative or adjunctive treatments.
results_summary: Essential oils, particularly sandalwood and ylang-ylang, showed strong antibacterial effects against Gram-positive strains and significant biofilm inhibition. Probiotic strains like Lactobacillus paracasei and Lactobacillus rhamnosus also demonstrated antimicrobial activity against specific pathogens.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains isolated from chronic wounds (43 strains tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioactive potential of Ferulago spp. essential oils, specifically their antifungal effects on dermatophytes and their wound-healing properties.
results_summary: Ferulago silaifolia essential oil, rich in α-pinene and cis-crysanthenyl acetate, showed strong antifungal activity against Microsporum canis and Trichophyton rubrum (MIC = 50 µg/mL), disrupted biofilms, and enhanced fibroblast migration, indicating potential wound-healing benefits.
population_specificity: Dermatophytes (Microsporum canis, Trichophyton rubrum) and fibroblast cells in vitro.
effective_dosage: 50 µg/mL for antifungal activity, 25 μg/mL for wound-healing assay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of glycerin-oxalic acid strips and essential oils in managing Varroa destructor infestations in bee colonies.
results_summary: The study found that glycerin-oxalic acid strips made of cellulose and cotton (2.3 mm) were the most effective, reducing mite infestation by 17.79%, while paper-cellulose strips achieved a 17.05% reduction. Essential oils (Beevital Hiveclean and Varro Red) were included in the treatments but their specific efficacy results were not highlighted in the abstract.
population_specificity: Bee colonies infested with Varroa destructor.
effective_dosage: Beevital Hiveclean (20 ml per colony), Varro Red (2 ml per frame).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-biofilm potential of essential oils from lemon, lemongrass, and lavender against clinical isolates of E. coli.
results_summary: The essential oils demonstrated notable biofilm inhibition (6-89%) and eradication (3-82.25%) properties, with MICs and MBCs ranging from 3.13-50 µg/ml. The findings suggest these oils may be a promising natural approach to combat E. coli biofilms.
population_specificity: 26 clinical isolates of E. coli.
effective_dosage: MICs and MBCs ranged from 3.13-50 µg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and antibiotic resistance-modulating activities of essential oils from Artemisia ludoviciana, Lippia graveolens, and Cosmos bipinnatus against multidrug-resistant bacterial strains.
results_summary: The essential oils demonstrated antibacterial activity with MICs ranging from 0.1735 to 65.6263 µg/mL. L. graveolens and A. ludoviciana EOs showed significant antibiotic resistance modulation, while C. bipinnatus EO did not exhibit notable activity.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis, and Salmonella typhi.
effective_dosage: MICs ranged from 0.0347 to 65.6263 µg/mL (specific dosing frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the chemical profiles and biological activities of essential oils from Ziziphus leucodermis stem and leaves, focusing on their potential against breast cancer, antimicrobial properties, and diabetes-related enzymes.
results_summary: The study found that leaf oil showed higher potency against breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231) and α-glucosidase enzyme, while stem oil exhibited stronger carbonic anhydrase II activity and antimicrobial effects against gram-positive bacteria and fungi.
population_specificity: In vitro (cell lines and enzymes)
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 133.5 ± 0.80 µg/mL (leaves) and 210.4 ± 0.20 µg/mL (stem) for breast cancer cells; 1.61 ± 0.08 µg/mL (leaves) and 2.39 ± 0.10 µg/mL (stem) for α-glucosidase; MIC of 12.5 ± 0.2 mm (stem) for Staphylococcus aureus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a microencapsulated blend of essential oils (cinnamaldehyde, eugenol, and thymol) and Ascophyllum nodosum seaweed meal on growth performance, intestinal function, blood biomarkers, and hepatic gene expression in broiler chickens.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with the essential oil blend improved feed conversion ratio, reduced mortality, enhanced digestive enzyme activity, upregulated nutrient transporter and lipid metabolism genes, and improved metabolic biomarkers in broiler chickens. No differences in carcass traits were observed between treated and control groups.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens (Arbor Acres chicks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of essential oils against non-growing Mycobacterium intracellulare to identify potential treatments for persistent infections.
results_summary: Thirty-four essential oils showed activity at 5000 µg/mL, with six (Ajwain, Oregano, Palmarosa, Thyme, Mountain Savory, and Litsea Cubeba) achieving 100% bacterial clearance after one day. Active components carvacrol (310 µg/mL) and citronellol (630 µg/mL) also demonstrated strong efficacy.
population_specificity: Non-growing Mycobacterium intracellulare bacteria in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial potential of essential oils against Pseudomonas aeruginosa isolates from canine otitis externa and their biofilm-degrading capacities.
results_summary: The study found that essential oils (cinnamon bark and leaf, bay, rosemary, thyme, and bitter orange) at a 2.5% concentration inhibited the growth of P. aeruginosa and degraded mature biofilms at both 30°C and 37°C.
population_specificity: Forty P. aeruginosa isolates from dogs with otitis externa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic efficacy of microemulsions formulated with cardamom oil, black seed oil, and olive oil, and assess their potential as innovative drug delivery systems for repaglinide.
results_summary: Cardamom oil-based microemulsions demonstrated superior drug release characteristics and significant improvement in antidiabetic outcomes compared to standard commercial repaglinide formulations, attributed to improved bioavailability and controlled release properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo studies implied animal models, but exact population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acaricidal effects of C. sempervirens essential oils and extracts against R. annulatus ticks and identify their bioactive compounds.
results_summary: The ethanol extract of C. sempervirens showed the strongest acaricidal effect, achieving 100% mortality of R. annulatus females at all tested concentrations (10-50%) after 14 days. The study also identified key bioactive compounds, including Eicosapentaenoic acid, and demonstrated significant antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Semi-engorged female R. annulatus ticks.
effective_dosage: 10-50% concentrations of ethanol, methanol, distal water, and chloroform extracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of essential orange oil (EOO) combined with cell-free filtrate (CFF) of Lactobacillus pentosus RS2 as antibacterial and antibiofilm agents against B. cereus RS1.
results_summary: The mixture of CFF and EOO effectively inhibited B. cereus growth and biofilm formation, with significant reductions in biofilm synthesis on commercial surfaces and altered expression of biofilm-related genes.
population_specificity: Foodborne pathogen B. cereus RS1 (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 400 μl ml-1 CFF and 16 μl ml-1 EOO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the α-glucosidase inhibitory (AGI) efficacy of citrus peel-derived essential oils, both alone and in combination with acarbose, for managing Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that citrus peel-derived essential oils, particularly valencene, carveol, and geraniol, showed potent inhibition against α-glucosidase but not α-amylase. Combining carveol or geraniol with acarbose exhibited synergistic effects on α-glucosidase inhibition, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits with reduced side effects compared to acarbose alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico study).
effective_dosage: 12.5 μg/mL acarbose combined with 2 mg/mL carveol or geraniol.
interactions: Antagonistic effects with α-amylase and synergistic effects with α-glucosidase when combined with acarbose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test new binary combinations of essential oils for their antibacterial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory activities, particularly against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli.
results_summary: Origanum vulgare L. showed strong antibacterial activity against all tested strains, including MRSA, and exhibited the best antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. Synergistic and additive effects were observed in certain EO combinations, along with biofilm reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of essential oils, tannins, bioflavonoids (ANAVRIN®), monensin, and their combination on daily gain, feed conversion, and rumen fermentation in finishing steers.
results_summary: EOTB increased dry matter intake compared to EOTB + MON, but no significant differences were observed in average daily gain or feed conversion ratio. The combination of EOTB + MON led to more stable volatile fatty acid concentrations in the rumen, suggesting potential complementary effects.
population_specificity: Finishing steers (441 kg body weight, 34.3 months old) fed a total mixed ration.
effective_dosage: ANAVRIN® at 0.35 g/100 kg body weight; monensin at 0.033 g/kg dry matter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nematicidal effects of Cinnamomum zeylanicum and Citrus aurantium essential oils on Meloidogyne incognita juveniles and compare their molecular mechanisms to the chemical nematicide Oxamyl.
results_summary: Cinnamomum zeylanicum showed higher toxicity (94.7% mortality) than Citrus aurantium (26.7% mortality) at 100 µg/mL after 24 hours. The study also found differential gene expression in nematodes treated with sublethal doses, suggesting distinct action modes between the essential oils and Oxamyl.
population_specificity: Meloidogyne incognita juveniles (J2)
effective_dosage: 100 µg/mL for mortality assessment; 0.78 µg/mL (sublethal dose) for gene expression analysis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential therapeutic effects of essential oils on psychosomatic aspects of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that various essential oils showed effectiveness in improving memory, learning, enzyme activity, oxidative stress, inflammation, and cognitive symptoms in Alzheimer's disease, suggesting their potential as complementary therapies. However, further human clinical trials are needed to validate these findings and determine optimal dosages and long-term safety.
population_specificity: Primarily in vitro and in vivo studies (animal and cell models), with implications for Alzheimer's disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of Citrus peel essential oils (CPEOs) on human glioblastoma cells and explore their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: CPEOs inhibited glioblastoma cell migration, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, increased intracellular Ca2+ and reactive oxygen species, and activated calcicoptosis-related pathways. The study suggests CPEOs have significant potential for glioblastoma treatment.
population_specificity: U251 human glioblastoma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether essential oils (garlic, cinnamon, and thyme) could inhibit pyomelanin production, biofilm formation, and virulence traits in pyomelanogenic P. aeruginosa, as well as their potential to enhance antibiotic sensitivity.
results_summary: Garlic, cinnamon, and thyme essential oils significantly inhibited pyomelanin production, biofilm formation, and virulence gene expression in P. aeruginosa. They also reduced bacterial survival in human blood, improved survival in a C. elegans model, and enhanced antibiotic sensitivity, particularly garlic oil when combined with colistin.
population_specificity: Pyomelanogenic P. aeruginosa (clinical isolate U804) and C. elegans as a model organism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sleep-inducing effects of five essential oils (Jasminum sambac, Magnolia denudata, Rosa rugosa, Aloysia citriodora, and Abies balsamea) on PCPA-induced insomnia in mice.
results_summary: The essential oils improved sleep latency and total sleep time, upregulated 5-HT1A and GABAARα1 expression, and mitigated insomnia-induced weight loss, with varying effectiveness among the oils.
population_specificity: Kunming (KM) mice with PCPA-induced insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the additive antipathogenic effects of essential oils (specifically Oregano EO) and probiotics for treating acne vulgaris and eczema complicated by secondary infections.
results_summary: Oregano EO demonstrated strong antipathogenic effects against Cutibacterium acnes and Staphylococcus aureus without adversely affecting probiotic growth. Combining Oregano EO with probiotics in freeze-dried patches significantly improved pathogen inhibition, surpassing commercial acne patches.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a compound essential oil (CMFXFEO) derived from Magnoliae Flos and Xanthii Fructus in treating allergic rhinitis (AR) in a rat model and to identify its active components and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: CMFXFEO significantly reduced allergic symptoms, inflammatory cell infiltration, and serum IgE levels in OVA-induced AR rats. Network pharmacology and molecular docking identified key therapeutic targets and pathways, suggesting CMFXFEO's potential anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: OVA-induced allergic rhinitis rat model (n=20, divided into 4 groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chemical composition of essential oils from Mentha rotundifolia and Chrysanthemum coronarium and evaluate their toxicity to Tuta absoluta larvae in-vitro.
results_summary: The study found that the essential oils were toxic to T. absoluta larvae, with LC50 values of 2.88% for M. rotundifolia and 1.07% for C. coronarium, inducing 50% mortality within 7 days. Both oils showed similar insecticidal efficacy by contact.
population_specificity: Tuta absoluta (tomato leafminer) larvae in-vitro.
effective_dosage: LC50 concentrations of 2.88% (M. rotundifolia) and 1.07% (C. coronarium).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing dairy cows with a mixture of essential oils (Agolin) would reduce enteric methane emissions, improve nutrient digestibility, nitrogen utilization, and lactational performance.
results_summary: The study found that essential oil supplementation (1 g/day) did not affect dry matter intake, nutrient digestibility, nitrogen balance, milk yield, feed efficiency, or methane emissions in dairy cows. No positive effects on lactational performance or methane reduction were observed.
population_specificity: Multiparous lactating Holstein cows (n=32) averaging 95 days in milk and 698 kg body weight.
effective_dosage: 1 g/cow per day (Agolin, containing coriander seed oil, eugenol, geraniol, and geranyl acetate).
study_duration: 10-week data collection period following a 3-week adaptation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer activities of Citrus peel essential oil (CPEO) through cell experiments.
results_summary: CPEO increased antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced lipid peroxidation, decreased nitric oxide production and proinflammatory cytokines, and induced apoptosis in cancer cells via the mitochondrial pathway.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 cells (macrophages) and U87 cells (glioblastoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined antimicrobial activity of a phage cocktail (MS2+T7) and essential oils (cinnamon, clove, oregano, and thymol) against Escherichia coli ATCC 15597.
results_summary: The study found that combining phage cocktails with essential oils (cinnamon, clove, oregano, and thymol) significantly enhanced antimicrobial activity, reducing E. coli by over 5 log CFU/mL. The lowest relative fitness and mutant frequency were observed in E. coli treated with these combinations, suggesting synergistic effects.
population_specificity: Escherichia coli ATCC 15597 (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 1/2 × MIC for each essential oil (cinnamon, clove, oregano, and thymol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a blend of cinnamon, oregano, and eucalyptus essential oils could enhance immune function, reduce inflammation, minimize oxidative stress, alter intestinal microbiota, and improve growth in calves.
results_summary: The essential oil blend improved immune and antioxidant responses, enhanced feed efficiency, and reduced acute-phase proteins but did not affect weight gain or intestinal microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Male Holstein calves (approximately five days old).
effective_dosage: 5 mL/feeding twice daily for the first 15 days, then 10 mL/feeding until day 60.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the traditional use of Ammodaucus leucotrichus essential oil (ALEO) by assessing its relaxant and spasmolytic activities and comparing them to its major constituent, perillaldehyde.
results_summary: ALEO and perillaldehyde demonstrated dose-dependent spasmolytic effects on rabbit and rat jejunum, with perillaldehyde showing higher potency. The spasmolytic effect was attributed to non-competitive antagonism of calcium channels and muscarinic receptors, supported by molecular docking studies.
population_specificity: Isolated rat and rabbit jejunum (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and analyze data on essential oils (EOs) and antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) effective against MRSA, creating a database for future drug development.
results_summary: The study curated 863 EOs (671 unique) reported to be effective against MRSA, highlighting their potential as alternative treatments. The database, TAMRSAR, was developed to facilitate further research and drug development efforts.
population_specificity: Not specified (data compiled from PubMed articles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial effectiveness of essential oils (Coridothymus capitatus, Thymus capitatus L., and Thymus serpyllum) combined with tetracycline against tetracycline-resistant Salmonella enterica strains from the swine food chain.
results_summary: The study found that essential oils increased the susceptibility of tetracycline-resistant Salmonella strains to tetracycline, with synergistic and commutative effects reducing the required inhibitory concentration from 256 to 4 μg/mL. Thymol, carvacrol, linalool, and other terpenoid components were identified as key molecules enhancing the antibacterial activity.
population_specificity: Tetracycline-resistant Salmonella enterica strains isolated from the swine food chain.
interactions: Interaction with tetracycline was noted, showing synergistic effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of essential oils and organic acids mixtures (EOA) in drinking water for improving growth performance and intestinal health in broilers challenged with necrotic enteritis (NE).
results_summary: EOA supplementation significantly reduced Clostridium perfringens load, improved gut microbiota diversity, and reduced intestinal injury markers in NE-infected broilers, with EOA2 showing better effects than EOA1.
population_specificity: One-day-old Arbor Acres male broilers
effective_dosage: 0.2% EOA1 or EOA2 in drinking water

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify essential oils with antifungal activity against Candida albicans and evaluate their efficacy, synergistic effects with amphotericin B, and active components.
results_summary: The study identified 48 essential oils with antifungal activity at 1% concentration, with 14 maintaining fungicidal effects at lower concentrations (0.25% and 0.125%). Five oils (Cinnamon, Satureja montana, Palmarosa, Lemon eucalyptus, and Honey myrtle) showed strong inhibitory effects on stationary-phase Candida albicans and hyphae elongation, with synergistic effects observed when combined with amphotericin B.
population_specificity: Candida albicans (in vitro study)
interactions: Synergistic effects noted with amphotericin B

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemical composition of Thymus serpyllum essential oil (EO) and assess its larvicidal and ovicidal activity against Spodoptera litura, as well as its effects on antioxidant detoxification enzymes.
results_summary: The study found that T. serpyllum EO, primarily composed of thymol, p-cymene, and γ-terpinene, demonstrated significant larvicidal and ovicidal activity against S. litura, with LC50 values of 0.606 and 0.664 mg/mL for larvae and an EC50 of 0.905 mg/mL for eggs. The EO also altered enzymatic activity, reducing ESTs and GST while increasing AChE.
population_specificity: Spodoptera litura (omnivorous pests)
effective_dosage: LC50 values of 0.606 and 0.664 mg/mL for larvae, EC50 of 0.905 mg/mL for eggs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the phylotype-selective efficacy of essential oils (EOs) from Thymus x citriodorus, Thymus mastichina, and Cistus ladanifer compared to Melaleuca alternifolia against Cutibacterium acnes in both planktonic and biofilm forms.
results_summary: Thymus x citriodorus EO showed lower planktonic MIC values and effectively reduced biofilm biomass and metabolic activity in phylotype IA1 strains, outperforming tea tree EO. Virulence traits varied by phylotype, with IA1 strains producing higher biofilm and lipase levels than phylotype II strains.
population_specificity: Cutibacterium acnes strains (one collection strain and seven clinical isolates).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of essential oil from Asarum sieboldii Miq. (ASO) on allergic rhinitis (AR) using bioinformatics, network pharmacology, and in vivo/in vitro experiments.
results_summary: Nebulized ASO improved tight junction-related factors, reduced nasal epithelial inflammation, decreased inflammatory cell infiltration, and alleviated allergic symptoms in AR-induced mice. It also reduced ROS production, restored mitochondrial membrane potential, and inhibited proinflammatory cytokines linked to MAPK/NF-κB pathways.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with OVA + PM10-induced allergic rhinitis and RPMI2650 nasal epithelial cells.
effective_dosage: 0.0002% and 0.02% ASO administered via nebulizer for 5 min per day, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant, anticholinesterase, and anti-inflammatory activities of essential oils from Azorean Cryptomeria japonica biomass residues for potential use in Alzheimer's disease complementary therapy.
results_summary: The CJRRB-EO showed anti-AChE and anti-BChE activities, while CJS-EO had stronger anti-BChE activity. Both EOs exhibited anti-inflammatory effects, with CJRRB-EO being comparable to diclofenac. Toxicity tests indicated CJRRB-EO was less toxic than CJS-EO.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and molecular docking studies).
effective_dosage: Anti-inflammatory activity tested at 2.21 μg/mL; IC50 values for anti-AChE (1935 µg/mL) and anti-BChE (600 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of essential oils as quorum sensing inhibitors to reduce virulence in multidrug-resistant strains of Klebsiella pneumoniae.
results_summary: The study found that fifteen essential oils exhibited anti-quorum sensing activity, reducing capsular polysaccharide, exopolysaccharide, and siderophore production, and inhibiting biofilm formation in MDR K. pneumoniae strains. The results suggest potential for essential oils in developing alternative strategies to combat infections caused by these resistant bacteria.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant strains of Klebsiella pneumoniae.
